Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Effect of Cohesion on Size and Statistics of Avalanches in Granular Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336116
PI: Lehman

1336634
PI: Dahmen

This collaborative project aims at understanding the effect of cohesion on the avalanche statistics in granular materials, and at predicting or minimizing catastrophic avalanches. Experimental results obtained with simple granular bead piles with tunable cohesion will be compared with the predictions of simulations and theoretical models.

The project will systematically study the effects of cohesion on the statistics of slip avalanches on bead piles. Past work has focused on the dynamics of non-cohesive granular materials; new preliminary results show that cohesion can lead to catastrophic effects that cannot be treated as a small perturbation to the non-cohesive studies. The College of Wooster has developed a unique experimental apparatus utilizing magnetic fields to systematically vary the cohesion between steel beads, and the University of Illinois has developed an analytical mean-field model with one shear-stress weakening parameter to model the effects of cohesion on granular materials. The collaborative effort between the two institutions will explore the universal (i.e. detail-independent) effects of cohesion on avalanches and will identify the experimental tuning parameters that determine the size and probability of the catastrophically large avalanches. The experimental system consists of beads that are slowly dropped onto a conical pile that occasionally avalanches. The analysis focuses on statistical properties of the avalanches, such as the probability of particular avalanche sizes and durations, the time between avalanches, and size and recurrence time of the largest events. All of these properties are measured as a function of the amount of cohesion, the amount of initially added energy, the size of the pile, and other experimental parameters. The analytical part of the project uses tools from the theory of phase transitions and the renormalization group to derive predictions for the intermittent avalanches.

Cohesion is relevant to a wide variety of avalanching systems, and these results could ultimately be used to minimize the occurrence of hazardous, catastrophic avalanches in these systems. Understanding the effect of cohesion will also allow better control over the flow of powders, sands, building materials, and agricultural grains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to elucidate the effects of cohesion—the tendency of granular materials to stick to one another—on the flow of these materials. New preliminary results obtained during the project show that cohesion can lead to unusually large “avalanches”—uneven, jerky flow characteristics that can disrupt move macroscopic amounts of matter, similar to catastrophically large landslides. Both the theoretical model and the experiments in this study show that increasing the cohesion makes these large avalanches even larger. Understanding the effect of cohesion allows better control over the flow of powders, sands, building materials, and agricultural grains.

Intellectual Merit: As a result of this project, a better understanding was obtained of how cohesive granular materials deform and what this means for avalanche formation. In particular, both theory and experiment show that higher cohesion can lead to larger avalanches. Cohesion between the grains increases the size of the largest avalanches, thus making them potentially more destructive.

Cohesion also affects whether large avalanches occur regularly or not: both theory and experiment show that for higher cohesion, the large avalanches recur more periodically, and thus become more predictable. The statistics of the sizes of the avalanches and of the times between the avalanches can be used to not only obtain information about the underlying cohesion, but also to predict statistical aspects of future avalanche behavior.

The study shows that the predictions obtained from the theoretical model agree with experimental data on a granular pile that has tunable cohesion. The simple model captures the symmetries of a wide range of systems, so that several results and the new analysis methods are likely transferrable to many other systems having avalanches, including earthquakes, landslides, and metallic alloys that slip when slowly deformed.

Broader Impacts: Cohesion is relevant to a wide variety of avalanching systems, and these results could ultimately be used to develop methods to minimize the occurrence of hazardous, catastrophic avalanches in these systems. This collaborative synthesis of experiment and theory provides new ideas, approaches, and frameworks that are applicable to a range of geometries, such as sheared granular materials and hopper flow.

This interdisciplinary project has collaboratively trained both undergraduate students and graduate students in modern scientific methods from a variety of research areas, ranging from statistical physics, computational physics, and materials science and engineering, to earth science and soil mechanics. The undergraduates at the College of Wooster performed the experiments and gained insight into theoretical research carried out at the University of Illinois. The students at Illinois learned about experimental methods and how to communicate their theories to experimentalists. Publication of the results of this work contributes to the education of future scientists and the general public.
